Dearest Mummie + Grandma:
You will probably be together by the time this reaches you so you can both read it. Am enclosing samples of my dress goods.
The crepe de chine is the outer part. The other composes the under body which doesn't show. It isn't done yet but will be tomorrow in time for me to wear it to the dance and card party given by the Eastern Star at Edison Park to which Mrs. Wilson has invited us.
The goods are awfully pretty and the dress is

I used only 2, and that was almost too much. You see, the recipe doesn't call for any milk and only ½ cup of water to be used in the chocolate part, so there is hardly any moisture to wet up the flour except the eggs. I think there must be some mistake as it seems as though there ought to be some milk in it. I wish you would send me the recipe for cream pie if you have it. I am awfully hungry for some. Also the recipe for Cousin Hetty's marshmallow cake. I made an apple pie according to Nellie Zeh's recipe last Sunday and it was very good. The crust was especially nice. I used 1 ¼ (one and one fourth) cups of flour, half teaspoon of salt, a little over a third of a cup of lard (with a little cotosuet) which I chopped into the flour with a knife. Didn't touch the dough with my hands until it was ready to roll out. Added enough water (mixing with the knife) to make it stiff enough to roll out. Then proceeded the usual way. I wish you could have some of it. I will make one for you some time; maybe two of them.
Must stop now and write some letters for the Krueger. 
With heaps of love to you both, 
Katharine.
P. S. Grandma, will send you some other hairpins in a day or two. 
Dear Mother: Katharine forgot to tell you that Mrs. Halpim? paid us a visit. She is some girl. unknown does not have to do much talking when she is around. She does it all. Now, in regard to the oranges, will say that I went to see several fruit dealers and they would be willing to buy your oranges but say that they could not afford to pay the transportation charges on them. Kimze's? buyer told me yesterday to ask you if you could get up a carload of oranges and if you can, what unknown could you make. He says, "that the only way they can handle them is by the carload lot", as by getting them in this way they would be able to eliminate the high cost of transportation.
Must stop now and take care of Krueger
With love
Max

4642 N. 46TH AVE.
CHICAGO, ILL.
Jan. 21, 1914.
Dearest Mummie:
I sprained my left wrist last Monday afternoon on my way home from the grocery store, so I can't use the typewriter. The walks are very icy which accounts for my fall. I wasn't hurt otherwise, but this is enough. I bathed it in hot water quite a bit and it is on the mend, but there is still room for improvement.
Seems to me your nickel or rather dime show is awful stingy with its pictures if it only gives two reels. Out here we get a big picture like the Million D.M., and 4 or 5 other pictures, about 7 reels in all, for a dime. Why don't you start up a rival show? I suppose it would take quite a bit of capital to begin it, though. 
Mr. Cole finished paying for the December rent yesterday. It took him quite a while, didn't it? I am enclosing P.O. order for $9.00, keeping out $6.00 for our presents, thanking you muchly. As soon as my

Caption-Abstract: Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library).
Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library).
Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library).

element_texts.text: Completed

wrist is well, little Hub and I will both sally forth to purchase our gifts. As soon as I get my camera I shall try to take a very striking portrait of puss-cat and send you some. 
Glad Mr. Thomas enjoyed his visit with you and made himself agreeable.
Some friends of the Wilson's have invited both them and ourselves over to play cards Saturday evening. I hope my hand will be well enough so I can shuffle. If not, somebody else will have to do it for me.
Yes, that will be a fine way to spend the $10,000. I expect them to mail me the check next month. It would be just like their orneryness, though, to mail it to somebody else.
Oh well, if I don't get that, I may get a prize in the scenario contest, a mere trifle of $250.00 or so.
I got out my algebra yesterday and beginning at the beginning, worked my way through to subtraction. Am going to review all that I studied in first year, then take up geometry.
Too bad the folks in A. P. can't get a market for their fruit. So many people up here would be glad to get it. 
Lots of love, Katharine.

Ducky Mum and Grandma, –
Will write you while I am waiting for my cream piee? pies? to cool. The hub is almost as fond of it as I, just as fond, I guess, so I have it as often as possible. I made a lovely cocoanut cake the other day after the recipe in my new cookbook and it was fine. Max said he never had tasted better cake, so I felt quite proud and pleased. Would have sent you some of it by mail only I was afraid that it would crumble and become stale before it reached you.
We went over to the Baker's on Sunday and had a very pleasant time. Stopped on the way to see Jo but she had gone down town. The old "J", however, was at home and asked us to come up and see

CHICAGO, ILL.
Told hub to mail you part of Sunday's paper, but I guess he forgot. Will remind him tonight.
March 11, 1914.
Sweet? Tweet? Mummie–
Just now got your letter. So sorry you have been working so hard. Are you getting good pay for it? What you have been doing ought to bring you at least $5.00 a day, I think. What a "damned" nuisance to watch over the excretory functions of so many children. One is plenty, I think. I forgot to say in my last letter that we way Draverman?. he was at home, but Jo was not. He is the same pimply faced critter as ever. He said that the paper was not doing very well and it certain by looks far from prosperous. Every issue is chuck full of bum advertising, such as "Can we not make you plump" "Why be fat"? "Dr. Bunkerino's soothing syrup" etc. etc. Only about three articles in the whole paper and B.B.'s sprinkled generously throughout. Our washlady has a cat which has lately become a mother and I am to have one of the kittens as soon as they are weaned. Max is looking out for a puppy too, so I may have quite a managerie before long.
Sunday three of the club girls, Ruth, Ethel and

Ella, came out to call on us. We had a nice little visit and they enjoyed very much looking at my baby things. They spoke of having the stork shower at one of the girls' houses, some club night, and asked me when would be most convenient. I suggested some time early in April, so it will probably be in about 3 weeks. I have one slip made, the kind with a draw string in the hem, and expect to make about 4 more of the same kind. People's ideas differ so on matters of clothing for infants that it is somewhat difficult to decide certain points. The one that I am considering just now is whether or not to make any white nainsook or muslin petticoats. An article in the Tribune says a baby should have 6 of them and 4 flannel ones. An article in Physical Culture says one ought to provide plenty of flannel petticoats but that the other kind is quite unnecessary. That is you want to make one rather elaborate white petticoat to go with the best dresses, all right, but that others are not needed. I made one plain white petticoat

supper. It is such a satisfaction to be able to cook well. I am getting to be quite a "shark" in that direction and enjoy my housework very much. Doc is not home yet! I shan't expect him or look for him until he actually arrives bag and baggage. Of course, he expects to get the money "this week" as it has been for a good many weeks past, but I have given up hope. image PHYSICIAN & SURGEON image Joseph William Zeh, B.S., M.D.
4642 N. 46TH AVE.
CHICAGO, ILL.
March 16, 1914
Dearest Mummie + Grandma:
We have been having lovely weather for a week or so and the snow is all melted. Yesterday, Max and I had a late breakfast and went to Lincoln Park. Saw the usual things–the mandril the various monkeys, birds, storks, etc. Lots of the ducks in the bird house were floating around peacefully on the little lagoon, fast asleep. They looked very funny–like little toy boats, drifting about aimlessly. I heard the first robin Saturday morning. My! it sounded good! I supposed there are robins all the year round at Avon Park?
Your lovely package of orange goodies came this morning. Thank you very much. What is the name of it and how do you make it?
I spoke to Nelllie Zay about the sympton book and she said that she would send it. Domestic affairs between her and Doc are not yet settled. He was here alone when we got back from the park yesterday and had supper with us. They talked matters over when she and Ralph got back from downtown and he promised to have the money this week Saturday.

Doc has about decided to trade the house for a drugstore located on the South side, near 22nd Street, I think. It seems to be a flourishing business, and he would have an excellent opportunity to establish a good private practice in connection with it. This appears to me to be a wise move, considering the fact that the Blair Remedy Co. is not doing well and probably will go to pieces in another year. Since those are his plans, Max and I have talked the matter over with him and about decided to take a small flat on the south side for a year or so, anyway. Max will continue with the Krueger, of course, and has really fine prospects of making a big thing of his printing business. We would all like better than anything to take the house in Glen Ellyn, but when Doc gets the drugstore on his hands he will have to live right on the premises, for a time, at least, and the G. E. place is almost too large for just Max and me to handle. Probably, in a year or two, we shall move out there or into some suburb because we are both agreed that the city is not a good place to bring up a child.

image PHYSICIAN & SURGEON image Joseph William Zeh, B.S., M.D.
4642 N. 46TH AVE.
CHICAGO, ILL.
March 18, 1914
Ducky Marder, –
The drug store deal has fallen through after all so I suppose Doc will continue with the Blair Remedy Co. I am rather glad on many accounts–first because we won't have to move (which would be quite a job at this stage of the game) second, because we can have a garden this summer (which we could not have if we moved to a flat) and third, because we won't have any rent to pay, which is quite an item to consider. Doc was willing to carry out his end of the bargain but the Drug Store Man had evidently run across some better proposition and backed out. Nell Zay? is getting ready to move out and spent most of the day clearing out her bedroom, looking up boxes to pack her pictures in, etc. etc.
I made another flannel petticoat this morning and got it all done, buttonholes and everything. I enjoy my sewing so much and it is such a satisfaction to make the things all myself and get them right. I wish you could see them and you probably can in a month or two. Mummie, could you arrange to leave there for Chicago about the first of May? Of course, I don't expect to be confined until the 24th but I may have miscalculated and would like to have you in time. We will send you your railroad fare beforehand, of course, so you won't have that to worry

about. I am busy with all sorts of things when I am not sewing, but I have plenty of time for my walks, reading, etc. Some afternoon soon, Mrs. Wilson, Nell Zay? and myself are planning to go and visit Mrs. Schleh, you know, the one who gave you and Jo Kaneko a reading. I haven't anything in particular that I care to find out about unless it were Max's business affairs and as they seem to be running very smoothly, I guess there is nothing to be feared for from? that quarter. But I never have had a reading in my life and just out of curiosity if for no other reason, I should like to go to her. I just now got a very friendly letter from Elaine, congratulating me and offering to come and keep house for me during my lying-in. Lord I'd just as soon have a hornet around as to have her! She is trying her best to get to Chicago and settle down with us and I suppose she thought this an excellent opportunity. It froze up last night and was pretty cold all day but not (4 p.m.) the sun is out and things look more cheerful. I'm afraid the "first robin" will get chilblains on his toes. I'm anxious to get out and start a flower garden so I hope the warm weather will hurry up. I'm so hectic to get a glimpse of you, Mummie, that I can hardly wait. I must stop now and mail this while out for my walk. 
Nellie is going to sell the piano so I expect we will get ours from the Bakers very soon.
Heaps of love,
Katharine

4642 N. 46TH AVE.
CHICAGO, ILL.
March 25, 1914.
Ducky Marder: 
I am waiting anxiously for a letter from you, telling whether or not you can come. I so hope that you can. It seems ages since you went away and now it is spring again. This is a fine day though very windy. So warm that the furnace fire makes the house uncomfortable, but we can't let it go out as we need it when the sun goes down. I took a nice walk yesterday and heard robins and a bob-o-link singing. The day before I heard a meadow lark.
I have finished hemming the diapers, 30 in all, (I did them on the machine) and I think that will be enough. If not, I can easily make others later on.
Sunday I did some ironing and made an apple pie. The washlady was unable to stay but half a day last week on account of a bad cold so she hadn't time to iron. Nellie Zeh is busy every day with her packing. Has got all her books packed and some of the pictures

Has made plans to leave by the first of May, anyway? and probably before. I don't know what she intends to do or where she expects to go and I doubt if she does either. Doc is still rooming of course, and dines mostly on corn flakes, being aflicted with stomach trouble. Max has got the industrial novelty works moved at last into the new place, 117 N. 5th Ave. and expects to move the Krueger on Saturday. He met with a sad accident yesterday. He was working at something or other in the new place, slipped, and threw out his hands to save himself. His palms came in contact with a couple of nails (one for each palm) so he now resembles Christ so far as his hands are conceived. The wounds are very painful but he has taken plenty of precaution against blood poisoning, using peroxide, etc. so I guess they will heal up all right. A day or two before this experience he nearly cut off the end of his thumb on his razor. The cut was pretty deep and bled a great deal. Doc said he cut several of the small veins, so you see is pretty well bunged up. I got a letter from Ethel saying that the girls were going to give me my shower this week Saturday evening at Elsie's house. She called me up this morning saying that. Elsie was unable to entertain this

week so it would be at Ruth's instead. I am to go out as early in the evening as possible then Max will call for me about 9:30. The washlady has promised to bring me a kitten the next time she comes. Max has been too busy to see about a pup. Don't know whether we will have one or not.
Mrs. Wilson invited me up to lunch yesterday to meet her sister-in-law and a young married lady who has a baby about the age of Mrs. Wilson's. (The sister-in-law is married too, but her baby died about two years ago. It was born at 7 months and should have been circumcised but the Dr. was afraid to do it because the baby was so tiny. When he finally did, it was too late and the baby died from absorbing into its system the urine which should have passed off.) The two women are pleasant enough but have no interest or thought for affairs outside their daily life, which seems to be the case with many women. tion registration, continued from previous page for the city election.
Do you know of anybody in Avon? Park who would like to subscribe for the Pictorial Review? The magazine is offering all sorts of nice prizes for a certain number of subscriptions: The subs are $1.00 a year and out of each dollar you are permitted to keep 25¢ and get these prizes besides. The latter are really worth while and I thought I should like to try for them. I am enclosing the letter which was sent me in reply to mine asking for information so you can see what their plan is. You needn't return it as I am keeping the order blank which was also sent. Rather a clever scheme on the part of the P.R. to increase its circulation.
Hope you have got well rested up from your nursing. Its a shame about that insurance policy. Did you sign anything in connection with it? Bud says he thinks if you didn't affix your signature to any blank or order of any sort, you are not obliged to pay anything on it. Better invesigate thoroughly before you make payment.
With heaps of love,
Katharine.

4642 N. 46TH AVE.
CHICAGO, ILL.
March 30, '14.
Ducky Mum and Grandma:
The girls gave me such a lovely stork shower last Saturday evening. It was at Ruth Doescher's house and everyone was there except Margaret Kelly who has recently resigned. The girls had invited Norine Crawford too and it was certainly a pleasure to see her again. She asked about you, Grandma, and sent her love. I arranged to meet Max at the station in time for the 10:20 train, but found when I got there that the guests were conspicuous by their absence and most of them arrived at about 9:00 when they had planned to come at 7:30. I told Ruth that I was planning to take the 10:20 but she said I couldn't get it and that seemed to dispose of the matter, in her mind at least. So, aside from worrying about Max, I spent a very delightful evening. Everything was very tastefully arranged for, depending from the chandelier, hung a blue and white crepe paper watering pot, from the spout of which hung blue baby ribbon streamers–10 of them–each fastened to a gift on the table below. The presents were all wrapped in white tissue paper and

Caption-Abstract: Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library).
Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library).
Forms part of the Midwest Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library).

element_texts.text: Completed

the effect was very pleasing. When the last girl had come and we sat down to supper, it was 9:30. The table was fixed up in regular stork shower fashion. A black and white stork was suspended from the chandelier. He was very natural looking and had real feathers in his wings. The place cards were decorated with the same appropriate design and I found mine at the head of the table. The napkins were "storkish", too. The favors were little stork images with boxes of little colored candies under them. Lettuce sandwiches, fruit salad with whipped cream, nuts, ice cream, cake, and coffee, were served. The cake was white frosted, with little candy corns on top forming the letters Greek letters Tau, Delta, Phi.
As soon as the supper was over with we adjourned to the parlor and the "shower" commenced. I sat in a chair at the table and opened the gifts, one by one, while the girls looked on. And Oh! they are all splendiferous! I'm so anxious for you to see them. There is a wonderful carriage robe, presented by Ella, and made by her. It is white, with beautiful embroidery, and a large bow of blue ribbon surmounts it. Then Norine gave me a nice soft blue and white blanket with rabbits outlined on it. Ethel presented a lovely pillow case, embroidered, made by herself. Elsie gave a dear little cap embroidered in blue silk, also hand made. Ruth Doescher and Ruth Nelson (the new member) each gave a lovely little sacque trimmed with blue ribbon and embroidered in blue silk. Mary gave me a pair of blue ribbon elastic bands with rosettes to keep up the baby's sleeves. Margaret Kelly sent a lovely little pair of blue and white footies; Lillian gave a tiny gold band ring with the initials Greek letters Tau, Delta, Phi engraved on the inside.

and last and best of all is a darling little dress from Nora. It is all hand embroidered most exquisitely. The bottom is buttonhole embroidered all the way round and finished off with lace. It is beautifully done as are all the gifts. When I finally got the things all opened and then packed away in a box, it was too late to get the 11 o'clock train and I told Ruth, on leaving to call Max up at the station and tell him I would be delayed. She couldn't get him, however, and when I got off the car I found him in front of the station on the Madison Street curb, anxiously watching every car. He was worried to death for fear something had happened to me and had been standing out in front for a long time. He enjoyed looking at the gifts ever so much, when we got home, but kept saying how glad he was to have me safe and sound and not to have learned that I had a miscarriage on the car or somewhere else. 
I found your bundle waiting for me when I got here. Thank you ever so much for everything, especially the little booties and mittens, though I don't think I had better use the latter. They are too precious. I put the curtains up in our bedroom Sunday and the slips on the pillows. The rose petals will be quite a

4642 N. 46TH AVE.
CHICAGO, ILL.
April 3, 1914.
Ducky Marder + Grandma:
The washlady brought my kitten this morning. It is coal black all over and has bluish grey eyes. Is about 2 months old and very lively. We have not yet determined its sex but the name "Ethiope" will do for either. I am having your prints made. Called for them Wednesday but they were not done so shall have to wait until tomorrow when I am to go and help Nellie Zeh pick out a hat. I got one a week ago. Bought a plain black straw shape ($2.95) a stick-up of roses and one single rose costing respectively 25¢ + 38¢. I trimmed the hat myself and it looks very well. Ralph has gone to Muskegon. He left Wednesday evening. Nellie Zeh took him and me to see E. H. Sothern in "If I were King". It was superbly acted and I enjoyed it immensely. I will save the program and tell you about it when you come. The story is too long to write.

Dr. Zeh came out and spent the night yesterday. First time he has been home since November. I guess he will be here right along now. I forgot to tell you before that he has decided not to take my case. Will get some friend of his instead as he feels rather squeamish about undertaking it since he is not in practice, besides its being right in the family, so to speak. Nellie Zeh put in her argument with Doc that she was privileged to stay until the first of May, but she is going to leave Wednesday! Would go Monday but wants to stay over Tuesday to vote. Max's new place is at 117 (not 115 as you had it in your letter) N. 5th Ave. on the 6th floor, room 68. They are going to have a Bell phone but it is not yet installed. Will let you know the number when it is ready. I bought some more flannelette yesterday and have made a nightgown for the coming infant.
So glad you are learning to swim. Then you can have a good time in the lake this summer. Must take my walk now and mail this.
Heaps of love,
Katharine

CHICAGO, ILL.
April 7, 1914.
Ducky Marmer + Grandma:
Nellie Zay is writing you a letter, Mum, so I will put one in with hers. Am enclosing the prints which I got last Saturday. Went down on that day with Nellie to pick out a hat for her but she decided to wait until her plume was cleaned before buying one. However, we looked at various shapes and styles, and sort of decided on one. Got two new nightgowns for myself, $1.00 apiece. Don't forget to let me know the fare from Avon Park up here, so I can send you the money. Perhaps you could come before May 1st. The sooner, the better, of course.
I am getting to be a very large lady. In fact, when I was down town Saturday, the traffic was nearly blocked on several occasions when people halted and turned around to get a better view of my dimensions. I didn't like it at all, at first, but am getting used to it now. The women, I find are the worst ones to stare. Very few men pay attention to me, for which I am very

I haven't heard from Helen for a long time, in fact, not since New Year's when we were out there. I must write her again soon and see if anything unusual is the matter. Nellie Zay is going down town today and I have asked her to get me some birth announcement cards. I think I can use 50, don't you? If you can make out a list of people to send them to that I am not apt to think of, I guess we can use 50 or even more, to good advantage.
N.Z. expects to move her household goods tomorrow down to the Goodrick docks where they will be put on the Muskegon boat. She herself, will go on the night boat Wed. evening. She would have gond Monday but wanted to vote today so postponed her departure.
Papa came over Sunday to see me. He looks well, only seems to be getting more bald. Business is very good with him but you couldn't tell it by his clothes. I showed him my stork shower outfit, and he seemed much pleased. N.Z. made the I spoke of having everything I needed now except the baby buggy, which I would have to get later. N.Z. said, "Oh your Papa is going to get you the baby carriage". I laughed and said "Yes, he will not".  Papa laughed too in a rather

So you are nursing again, Mummie? Don't work too hard. Perhaps it won't be so hard if there are no children in the family for you to look after. We are having great times with our Ethiopian cat. He caught two flies yesterday; one this morning, and ate them all with great relish. I think that he will be very useful in that capacity next summer. I fired a large basket of ashes? for him under the sink in the kitchen and he now pays frequent visits to it and is no trouble whatever. He spends his nights in the basement and his days all over the house. His favorite amusement is to go into the pantry, behind the door, and climb up

the ironing board which stands on end. When he reaches the top he stands there and shrieks pitifully until I come and take him down. He is a very bright little thing and we are all very fond of him, especially Max, who is supposed to hold a special aversion to cats. We are going to get Doc to "change" him, if he will. Some of the best articles I have ever read on the education of children and the new woman movement, are appearing right along in the Pictorial Review so I don't think any Florida people will feel "stung" if they subscribe.
Have just finished reading Man + Superman and enjoyed it very much. Papa brought me two books Sunday. "The Third Degree" + "Old Love Stories Retold" by Richard LeGallienne. I think he said that the latter is also the author of "The Golden Girl" or some such book that we have.
Must stop now so this can be mailed.
Are you going to Highlands this summer, Grandma?
Lots of love,
Katharine.

April 13, 1914.
Ducky Marder,–
Have been expecting a letter from you for several days but it hasn't come yet. I got the one saying you were still at Mrs. Elliott's and had had no chance to inquire about r.r. fare. Hope to get one tomorrow saying how much it is so I can send it right away. Then perhaps you can come before May 1st.
Yesterday was lovely. The first ideal Easter we have had for six or seven years. It is just as nice today and I hope the weather will continue to be like this! I'm getting so tired of wearing my blue dress and kitchen aprons! Nothing new, and even the former seems to be getting too small in the waist. But I haven't much longer to wait, have I?
I have just written Margaret Schoenfeld, inviting her to come in and visit me next Saturday or Monday. I wonder if the violets and other wild flowers are in bloom yet. Perhaps she will bring some if they are. Nellie Zeh has given me her $1.00 for a sub to the Pictorial Review but I have no other so far. I am trying

We expect to have the piano moved over from the Bakers' some time this week. Got my hair washed yesterday. Max helped me rinse it.
Max's telephone is in now. The number is Franklin 4826. He also has the same automatic that he had at the other place. Have been using Mrs. Wilson's occasionally, but I dislike to go up there every time I want to run a seam. Made another dress the other day. Have 8 now all together. Do you think that is enough?

April 18, 1914.
Dearest Mum,
Enclosed you will find (herewith, as we say in business) a money order for $35.00 which perhaps will aid you in coming to the far north. Max is going to find out today the exact fare from Cincinnati to Chicago. Approximately, it is either 9 or 10 dollars. Is there enough money circulating in A.P. to cash your money order? I know there used to be considerable difficulty in that direction at Highlands.
Margaret Schoenfeld is coming in on the 9:21 train today to pay me a visit. I asked her to stay over night, but she has to meet her grandmother at the N.W. station at 5 o'clock and go home with her. The grandmother will be in town shopping today. I will find out from M. whatever she knows about the place and how the Coles are caring for it.

Dr. Zeh has engaged Dr. Quinn for me, an Irving Park M.D. who has a large practice, among a large share of it being child-birth cases. He had just got back from one when Doc went to see him.
I'm glad you are having such good luck with your hens, Grandma. I wish I could see your plants. I know they are beautiful as you are always so successful with them. My conservatory is limited to two Boston ferns. One is rather thick and short, not very pretty, but the other is very graceful. I think the first one ought to be thinned out, but I don't exactly know how to go about it. Perhaps mother can give some suggestions when she comes.
I got one of the T bandages cut out and basted up yesterday. Max brought me one of the government pamphlets on the prenatal care of children. It gives some very valuable hints as to the nursing of the mother, lists of articles necessary for a home confinement, etc.
We are having lovely warm sunshiny weather and I think, Mummie, that you will be able to wear your thin dresses very comfortably. I hanker for the time when I shall be able to wear a thin dress without astonishing the populace.
Heaps of love,
Katharine

4642 N. 46TH AVE.
CHICAGO, ILL.
April 21, 1914.
Precious Mum:
Many thanks for the subscription. I was thinking of subscribing for Grandma myself, but I can send her something else. Glad she likes Collier's. Thank you for the clipping from the Post. Haven't got around to read it yet. Will do so tonight so Max can hear it. It looks as though it would be very entertaining. Congrats on your swimming progress. You will probably do better than I this next summer.
I want ever so much to meet you at the station, but I'm afraid it wouldn't be very safe. That basket proposition might really manifest itself. Then what would I do. Perhaps I can come, though. The reason it would be difficult is that I have no wrap to wear but my heavy coat. It is the only thing that fits and on these very warm days that we are having, the heat exhausts me more than anything else. Max will be there and hustle you out here so I can see you very soon.

I hope your train will be on time. My! It seems too good to be true! Less than two weeks!
Margaret came? O.K. last Saturday. I met her at the Mayfair station at a little after 9 in the morning. She brought me 13 lovely fresh eggs and so we had omelette for lunch, besides bread and butter fruit salad and cream pie. Wish you could have had some of everything. She says that Lake Glen Ellyn is going to be drained this summer and the land sold for lots. Isn't that a pity? The place will lose one of its most attractive features in the lake. Just think, no place to skate in winter, either, unless they flood a hollow somewhere. It seems that the owner offered to sell the lake and surrounding land to the town for a park but the inhabitants turned the proposition down, fearing a rise in taxes. We unpacked a small box of books last Sunday, just enough to go in the dining room cupboard. Mostly fiction and essays. It seems good to have them out. George Elliot, Cooper, Emerson, Carlysle Carlyle (that doesn't look right) and various novels.
Awfully warm today. Sat out on the grass with the black puss.
Heaps of love,
Katharine.

April 26, 1914
Ducky Mum:
Am answering your letter right away so you will be sure to get it before you leave. I'm so glad you are to take a Pullman. It would be very hard on you to travel otherwise for such a long distance. Max will meet you at the station at 6:50 or later depending on the train. 
Dr. Zeh takes the appeal, but not the Review, so you had better have the address changed on the latter. I can call up the office about it if you like. That certainly is going some for sewer connection. Just one demmed expense after another. I should make as few repairs as possible this year. If he wants other things done let him do them himself.
The piano and sewing machine came last Thursday and I was indeed glad to welcome them home. Dr. Zeh and Max are working around the house and garden this morning. Got some pictures hung, the kitchen floor mopped, and expect to plant some vegetables. Doc brought hom a rose bush and set it out last night. I'm going to try my hand at a strawberry

What do you think of the enclosed letter from Helen which came a few days ago? Needless to say, I was considerably surprised as I dare say you will be. It was to be expected though, I suppose. I bet all her relatives are mad enough to jump out of their skins. I wonder where she is living. She didn't say, and I didn't ask her in my reply, for I thought it might be somewhat embarrassing to her, in case they are rather hard up. Has he a job of any kind of some sort of trade or profession? I wonder how it will all turn out.
The weather is lovely. Just like summer. Hope it will be as nice when you come. Just think how soon it is! Next week will seem ages long. Hope Grandma will not get dreadfully lonesome. I will write her often and tell her all the news about the great grandchild.
Must stop now so Max can mail this when he goes for the paper. 
Heaps of love to you both,
Katharine

4642 N. 46TH AVE.
CHICAGO, ILL.
July 29, 1914.
Precious Mummie:
Ralph met us after a wait of an hour and a half. We had gone up to the main street to get a bite to eat and we saw him driving past the lunchroom window. Got into the wagon when our breakfast was eaten and drove over to a drygoods store where I purchased some elastic and clasps. I gloat over my bathing suit frequently. It is a lovely present and you were so good to hurry on it and let me take it with me. The weather is lovely. We had a pleasant drive out to Nellie Zay's place. It is a beautiful country around here. Not as I anticipated at all. True, there are no trees near the house but there are many of them in reach of the eye. The house is rather roughly finished but is very pleasant and the rooms are always nice and cool. I guess it was a false alarm about my having to work a lot as

I had very little to do yesterday except dishes and help with the meals and I enjoyed all I did do. Max began on the chicken house right away. He is putting in a partition at one end and is going to roof the building with tar paper. We are all getting along very pleasantly so far and I think it will continue. Max treats Ralph very nicely and I think everything will be all right. Nellie Zay is very nice and the goose hangs high. She is much disappointed because you did not come. P.M. here and must give him letter.
Love
K.

4642 N. 46TH AVE.
CHICAGO, ILL. crossed out
Muskegon, Mich.
July 31st 1914.
Dearest Mummie,
I didn't mean to bring my other letter to so sudden a conclusion but the post man appeared on the horizon and as he usually waits for no man, I ran down and flaged him and finished my letter by scribbling on a little tin box which he carries in his buggy.
I wish you could be here to have some of the lovely cream, butter, milk and eggs. They are the best ever. It seems very luxurious to sit down to a table with a big pitcher of real cream.
The chickens are very interesting. There are three sets little, medium and big and they all require different food and treatment. There is a little calf besides the cow and horse so it is no small task to care for the livestock. Nellie and I drove to town yesterday to buy feed, lumber for the chicken house, etc. Had a very pleasant trip.

I am enclosing Helen's letter. It seems she is going to have a baby after all. I hope everything will be all right with her. I wonder if her father knows about it. I wish you could come here for a few days. Nellie was much disappointed because you didn't come with us. Dr. Zeh expected to come a week from today and spend Sunday. Then we all go home Sunday night. Perhaps you could come then or some other time. Looking after the chickens is quite pleasant work. They are very tame and easy to manage. We are going over to Wolf Lake tomorrow and go swimming. Wish you were going too. I feel very rich with my fine new bathing suit. Have you been swimming lately? The weather has been very pleasant so far, neither too hot nor too cold. Max is getting very sunburned. 
Sorry puss-cat was on such poor behavior in our absence. Max scoffed muchly at his remembering us. 
I'm sure you would like it very much here. Don't you think you could come for a few days? Got 34 eggs yesterday. It is great fun to gather then.
Lots of love,
Katharine

CHICAGO, ILL.
Muskegon, Mich.
Aug. 4, 1914
Dearest Mummie:
Would have written you yesterday but went down town with N.Z. to buy feed, more lumber and take the eggs to market. Sold 3 crates each containing 12 dozen at 24 cents per dozen. In my birthday we went over to Wolf Lake 2 miles from here and went swimming then ate our lunch, drove around a bit, then came home. The water was nice and warm and I enjoyed the swim very much. Max tried to teach me to dive but I wasn't a very apt pupil. Max and I expect to go buggy riding tomorrow. It is very nice to have a horse on hand to use when you want it.
Glad you have been "godding about". Do you expect to leave by the 15th? Does that mean to enter the ham- hamburger, continued on next page

-burger hamburger, continuation of previous page business? I told Max about Thomas's proposition and he thinks that you could make good at it. He says I can go or not, just as I please but he says just as Verne did, that the people are not all that could be desired. Have you spoken to Miss Merrifield about going with you? N.Z. says to tell you and Dr. Zeh that she wants you both to come over Friday evening and she will meet you Saturday morning at the docks. She says she will be expecting you both. Max and I will leave here next Sunday evening, arriving in Chicago Monday morning. We both are enjoying ourselves very much. N.Z. has a fine cow who gives a copious supply of milk and cream. None of it is sold so what we don't eat goes to the chickens. It seems very luxurious to have a large pitcher of real cream on the table at every meal. Max is almost through with the chicken house and is helping Ralph build a fence around one of the smaller brooder houses. Got a card from Margaret yesterday and a nice letter from Grandma enclosing a dollar.
Lots of love,
Katharine.

4642 N. 46TH AVE.
CHICAGO, ILL.
Muskegon, Mich
Aug. 6, 1914.
Dearest Mummie:
Your letter from Elgin and one from aunt Emma came on the same mail. The latter enclosed a handkerchief ad the usual farm news. She always remembers my birthday, doesn't she?
Glad you had an opportunity to visit Helen and find out about things. Am very anxious to hear about it. Is Dr. Zeh intending to come or not? N.Z. is expecting him. We are washing today–the 2nd time since I have been here. Just your clothes fit for the washtub on account of the sand. N.Z. went to town alone yesterday to get some roofing for the hen house. I stayed at home because I had nothing clean to wear and because there was so much that needed to be done. Baked bread, ironed, got both meals (we have just two per day) washed dishes, etc.

We have our breakfast at nine and our dinner at three. It is a very satisfactory arrangement on a chicken farm because at the usual breakfast and dinner hours the folks are busy feeding the chickens or putting them to bed. The little ones can't put themselves to bed as they are all brooder chickens and are accustomed to being waited on. Did I tell you that I got a very nice letter from Grandma enclosing a dollar for my birthday?
Max said something the other day about not leaving until Monday evening if Doc comes, so if we don't turn up until Tuesday, you mustn't worry. 
We hope to go swimming once more before leaving for home.
Too bad about Mrs. Monoghan. Yes, indeed, you had a very cheerful visit, "take it all around like a cartwheel." 
With lots of love, 
Katharine.

Monday, 5 p.m.
Dearest Mummie:
Wanted to write you earlier in the day but was too tired to do anything but lie still when I had got the washing done and the floor scrubbed. I think after this I shall have the men do the floor Sunday morning or else I will do it myself some other day besides washday. Too smuch is enough.
So sorry you didn't get to see the Falls. Hope you can see them sometime. Wish I were there at Dart's with you. It must be lovely if it is anything like Highlands. I am mailing you the history of Europe in Sunday's Tribune.
Thank you for your "train letter." It was very realistic. I laughed frequently while reading it. I am scribbling down this letter just as the thoughts come to me, as I must

4642 N. 46TH AVENUE
CHICAGO
Sept. 24, 1914.
Dearest Mum:
I baked a devil's food cake yesterday morning and in the afternoon went over to Independence Park, taking Mrs. Wilson with me. I found the gym class in session when I got there so decided to go in swimming. I had brought Max's suit with me, so went to the locker rooms, got into the suit, put on a cap that the supervisor loaned me (I had forgotten my own) and got under the shower. The matron handed me a cake of soap and said that I was expected to wash my feet. I was somewhat surprised as my feet were not dirty, but found that they make everybody do that so as to keep the tank clean. The water felt pretty cold (that is, in the tank, the shower is warmer) but I had a good swim nevertheless. Mrs. Wilson stood at the side of the tank and watched. The instructor or supervisor or whatever her title is, is a girl just

a little older than myself, I believe, quite large and muscular. I didn't see her swim: She walked about in her bathrobe all the time I was there. She seemed to take an interest in my swimming, criticised my overhand stroke, etc. so I hope to be a good swimmer by the time I get through there. Lots of people urged me to try diving but I couldn't get up sufficient nerve. Before we left a lot of little kids 9 and 10 years old came over from school. Nearly all of them could swim well and some of them could dive. One little girl about 9 and small for her age jumped off the spring board and off the high ladder into 9 feet of water without even so much as a thought of fear. Mrs. Wilson was much taken with the place and is going to get both a swimming and gym suit and join the Wed. married ladies gym class. I am going to be transferred to that class, as it is much more convenient than going in the evening. They have given me a locker in which I have deposited my gym shoes. The postman has just brought my balsam pillow. Thank you ever so much, Mummie. I am going to town today and will get cloth to make a cover for it. The p.m. was quite interested in the package and said that he had got some balsam in Wis. once. That it was mean stuff to strip. While we were talking my door blew shut. Luckily the back door was open so I was not locked out.
Dr. Zeh + Max have agreed to clean the kitchen floor every Sunday morning so that matter is off my mind. I found a carpet beater down cellar yesterday and used it on the two small rugs in the front room. My! but they were dirty.
We are having lovely weather, sunshiny and a little cool, but just right for walking. The puss cat is growing nicely and takes an active interest in defending our yard from Mrs. Andrus' chickens. I have to watch him for fear he will do them mischief. 
So glad you are enjoying your visit at Darts. Hope you will get the newspaper all right. I addressed down at Anderson's and put the p.o. Big Moose Lake 90? Darts but guess it will be all right.
Much love,
K.

J.W. ZEH, B.S., M.D.
PHYSICIAN AND SURGEON
4642 N. 46TH AVENUE
CHICAGO
Sept. 26, 1914.
Ducky Marder:
I suppose you are on your way to the cousins' now so I will address this accordingly. Thursday afternoon I went out to 66th St and Union Ave. to see Bob (the printer's) wife. She is a very nice Scotch girl and I enjoyed my visit with her. She expects to be confined in January. I met her old grandfather, a nice old Scotchman with white hair and beard. I enjoyed hearing him talk. He has a very marked brogue, says, "Do ye, noo"? "bairn" "How is all wid ye"? etc. Yesterday I made crabapple jelly as Dr. Zeh brought home half a bushel of crabs. They were very nice and I got a little over two quarts. It takes a good many apples to make just a little jelly, I find. I was obliged to use two kettles besides the dish pan to cook them in and they got burned a little, which didn't impart a very good flavor to the jelly. I served some up at supper and Dr. Zeh and Max were both satisfied with it, so I guess it will do. Hope next time to do better.

Perhaps I will make some more grape jelly. 
Miss Ross has been out sewing this week but I supposed she will get the typewriter in a few days.
The balsam pillow is just fine. We all enjoy the smell of it so much; even the cat was sniffing it the other evening. He caught a bird this morning but hasn't eaten it. Guess I will have to bury it. I think it is a sparrow but am not sure.
The pansies are all growing nicely; The weather is cool, but very pleasant. 
Nellie Zay sent the capsules and I forwarded them to Mrs. Madsen. She called me up and said she received them and wanted N.Z.'s address so she could send her a money order. 
I went to gym class last night, Max accompanying me. Had a very pleasant evening. I only weigh 128 lbs. in my gym suit.
Did you get my letter and the paper? Puss cat sends love + best wishes. 
Lots of love from
Tairn.

PHYSICIAN AND SURGEON
4642 N. 46TH AVENUE
CHICAGO
Sept. 28, 1914.
Dearest Mum:
Got your letter this morning while I was doing my washing. Wasn't so tired after it this time as I didn't have to wash up the floor. Max mopped it yesterday. It looks fairly clean but I think I could improve upon it by scrubbing.
I think you did more than enough at Dart's to pay for your board. Glad you had such a nice time. You didn't say whether or not you received the paper I sent. Hope it reached you O.K. as it was the one containing the last instalment of the History of Europe. I am mailing you the main parts of yesterday's paper, including the comic section of the Sunday American which Max picked while we were at Lincoln Park, where we spent the afternoon. The newlyweds and their baby were pretty good this time, I thought. Perhaps Darwin would be interested in them. I started to write a poem the other day

putting down one line at a time as it cam to me.
I walk with eyes to westward and I see 
The sun with glorious rays outspread
Painting a beauteous canopy o'erhead
Which seems to stretch into eternity.
I marvel as I did long, long ago
And shall forevermore until I die
Whence come these wonders of the earth and sky
This power that makes earth's people live and grow
If I ever can think of something else to say and thus complete it, I will send it to you.
I like write poetry (?) it seems so easy for me. I can put down words and have plenty of rhyme and rhythum (that word looks awful but I haven't a dictionary handy) but it is hard to find a central thought and stick to it. Am becoming very much attached to the  balsam pillow. It must be lovely to live where that odor is in the air all the time. Love to the cousins and heaps to you. Tairn

4642 N. 46TH AVE.
CHICAGO, Ill.
Sept 30, 1914
Ducky Marder:
The stockings came this morning and I am forwarding yours with this letter. I am enclosing Mrs Hudler's letter which came at the same time.
Today is lovely as usual. I wish it were 'usual' all the year round. I wrote a moving picture scenario yesterday called "The Test of True Friendship". I am going to typewrite it and send it to the Universal Co. If they take it, though I feel sure they won't, I will send you a copy of it. Perhaps I will send you one anyway.
I cleaned the house up this morning. This afternoon I am going over to the Field House to see about my change in gym classes. 
They are paving our street at last. They began operations yesterday and are com-

pleting the work today. It is going to look very nice. They were working this morning in front of our place. The head boss spent most of his time this a.m. sitting on the front steps. It is now half past twelve and he is fast asleep under our pine tree. His hat is over his eyes and "take him all around like a button" he is not much of an ornament in the yard.
I should like to take a swim in the tank today, but my monthlies are due and I think I will wait until that business is over with. 
I wrote to Elaine yesterday. I didn't say anything about their plans for the winter. Thought she could volunteer the information if she wanted to.
Yesterday I cut off a piece of liver for Pusscat and threw it over the railing for him. The grey cat appeared on the scene very quickly from somewhere or other, grabbed up the liver and vanished. I tried to catch him but couldn't. He came around later looking very happy. I dare say it was the first square meal the poor thing ever had. It happened that there was a larger piece of liver that day so pussycat had his anyway. Hope you will have a good time at the farm. Lots of love, K.

Dear Mummie,
The enclosed letter was sent to you here in an envelope addressed by Leonora Pease.  I opened it thinking it might be from the latter concerning the picture we took of her & Mrs Felt, am forwarding it to you right away.
Evidently Mrs Felt sent you a letter which you did not receive. She gives no address but the letterhead so I suppose you will either have to write there or in care of Leonora.
Mrs Allen called me up this morning while I was busy cleaning up the pantry and asked me to attend the meeting of her club today at the LaSalle Hotel shall have to bake my bread before I leave so must stop.
Heaps of love, Tairn.

[Joseph William Zeh letterhead]
Oct 3, 1914
Ducky Mum,
Why don't I get a letter from you? Haven't heard anything since the letter you wrote last Saturday.
I am forwarding a letter from Beulah Huston. Have been pretty busy lately. Went to town Thursday to Mrs Allen's "I will" club. Bum stuff. Don't think I'll join.  They are all a good deal older than myself and I'm not specially interested in their work. They had Judge Newcomer speak. Never heard of him before and don't care if I never do again. The ladies all seemed much pleased with his talk. I wasn't. It consisted mostly of funny stories of the following type which he claimed were original but most of which I had read years ago. "One time I sentenced an old darkey

who had been stealing his neighbour's chickens. I asked him how he managed to do such a neat job with so many people near by. He said, "nevah yo mind, Boss, Don't try to learn how to steal chickens. Yo can get away with all the rascality yo want to by sticking to the bench wha yo all belong" etc. and more to the same effects. His talk was supposed to give us hints on civic betterment but I don't know of a single hint that he let drop. He spoke of the ballot for women in a very lordly fashion as though he himself had presented us with the 'privilege' as he called it. I regard it as a right, not a privilege.
Put up three quarts of tomatoes yesterday. I think there will be some to can next week too. Scrubbed the floor this morning and made a lemon cream pie this afternoon. This is the first I ever attempted and it looks very nice. 
I think I will do the floor myself after this. Max mopped it Sunday but it didn't look very well. Wish I could see you. Write to me soon.
Ever so much love, Katharine.

Glen Ellyn, Ill
May 21, 1915.
I am enclosing a handkerchief which belongs to you Mummie. I found it in the pocket of my old coat after moving.
Dearest Mummie & Grandma:
Got your letters just as I had mailed one to you. How nice of you, Grandma, to offer to make me some portieres. I shall be delighted to have them and I will rustle around immediately and collect silk things to send you. Max has a number of old neckties to contribute and Margaret has promised me some things. I shall probably get quite a quantity of silk from my neighbors. I think that I have nothing of my own to send except my old blue silk dress and a few ribbons.
Max and I are so pleased with our new or rather old home and are enjoying so much fixing it up and arranging and rearranging things. There are a few more pictures to be unpacked and hung and the lace curtains are still to be laundered and put up, but aside from those 
[left margin] Tomorrow is baby's 1st birthday.

things we are pretty well settled. I expect to go in town tomorrow to get a rug for the front room and some curtains for the library. We expect to get a new set of dishes soon and linoleum for the kitchen. Then we will feel quite elegant. Max is enjoying the garden so much and takes great pride in it and in the yard as well. The latter still looks quite neglected but he hopes to get it in shape before long. I made a lovely strawberry shortcake the other day and gave half of it to Margaret & her grandma. earlier in the day M. bought me a bowl of chicken noodle soup for my lunch. It had a large piece of chicken in it and was fine. Our exchange of "food gifts" in the neighbourhood amuses Max very much.

the gossip I can think of. Mac? is still in Chicago. He came out Sunday and spent the night. Seemed much pleased with the place.
Have had lots of rain lately and very cool weather. Much warmer today but such a high wind blowing and can hardly walk. Had a very hard rain in the middle of the night. The drops sounded like gravel coming down on the roof.
Found the film of Grandma Bell and will have the prints made and mail all according to directions. Did you receive the money that Max mailed you about a week ago? Perhaps it wasn't quite so long ago as that, but you should have it by now.
Pusscat is very happy in his new home and enjoys prowling about the yard. So glad you are feeling better, Grandma. Don't work too hard on the portieres. It is lovely of you to make them for me. I will send the silk as soon as possible.
Lots and stacks of love, Katharine

On board the good ship Virginia. Goodrich Line. Enrolee to Muskegon. [5-29-15]
Dearest Mummie & Grandma:
You will be somewhat surprised to see  by the above from where I am writing - no more surprised than I was yesterday morning at Hub's office to get a letter from Nellie Gay saying that she had run a rusty nail into her foot and wasn't able to get about and wanted me to come and stay with her for a time. She didn't say how badly she was hurt so don't know how long I shall have to stay. The boat hasn't left Chicago yet and people are still running up and down stairs with clashing keys and slamming suitcases. It has rained all day today and is still hard at it. It seems as though I never saw a rainier spell in this part of the country. It is about as bad as no rain at all and the crops new at a standstill. As I came through the

vicinity of the Desplaines river today I noticed that the rains had made quite a lake. If it keeps on the tracks will be flooded. If I am not back within a week I will have Max or Margaret mail the silk pieces that I have collected. Mrs. Johnson said she had a number of things I could have but she hasn't given them to me yet. Pusscat has been laid up recently with two swollen paws, one front and one hind one on alternate sides. I don't know what could cause them unless he has eaten something that was poisoned. He doesn't eat much except warm milk and sleeps night and day. He still limps very badly but I guess he will get well in time. He can't bear to have his paws touched. Bought a rug for the front room yesterday, a 6 x 9 Axminster at $13.00. It was delivered this morning together with the curtaining I purchased for three bedrooms and the library. Wish you could see it all. I'm sure you

SUN FLOWER POULTRY FARM
STRICTLY FRESH EGGS OUR SPECIALTY
R. R No. 4
MUSKEGON, MICH.
June 5, 1915.
Dearest Mummie & Grandma:
It is a quarter of six a.m. and the handiest time to write a letter on the above poultry farm. I've been quite an early bird for a week now and as I go to bed a couple of hours earlier than usual, I don't notice it much. Nellie's foot is steadily improving and doesn't pain her nearly as much as it did. She is walking now, without the aid of a chair, using the heel of her injured foot. She is very jubilant over the fact that her own special treatment (hot water and savina) made the consulting of an M.D. unnecessary.
There are 250 big hens and 200 little chickens on the place, mostly white leghorns. The latter dine 5 times a day so what with feeding them and attending to the housework I am aplenty busy. At noon the cow and her eldest son come to the back door and put their noses in, setting up

a great clamor, to indicate that they are ready to drink all the water you may care to pump for them. Today is bread baking day. I made a cake yesterday which turned out very nicely. It had no excuse for not doing so for I made it with real butter, fresh eggs and sour cream. We have real cream on everything, and very fine it is. The cow's younger son is about 2 months old. He consumes vast quantities of skim milk but we get all the cream. Got such a nice loving letter from Max yesterday. It was quite a treat to read it. He wants me to come home right away. I expect I shan't stay longer than one week more so any letters you write that will arrive later than the 11th, had better be sent to Glen Ellyn. Was so glad to get your nice letter yesterday. Margaret forwarded it to me. Max said that on Decoration Day, he and Doc had dinner at the Kopp's and supper at the Schoenfeld's. He likes it very much in G. E. and thinks the

people are "regular folks". He said he was going to play ball Sunday at Lincoln Park on a team which one of his paper salesmen belongs to. How I wish I could be there to watch him! I told him I wanted him to play again just as soon as I came back.
Nellie Z. has sold her piano so I got rather lonesome for ours to play on. I went over to one of the neighbour's the other evening and played theirs for a few minutes but half the family had retired when I got there so I felt pretty squeamish about staying any length of time. The people out here just toil and labor all the time, stopping only to eat and sleep. Sunday is like all the other days. I don't see what the use of living is, if one has to spend all one's time that way.
Wish you could see the eggs I gather every evening. They usually come to the brim of a large pail. when they are cleaned and assembled in large

baskets they look very nice. Max said in his letter that pussycat was all right again and I feel greatly relieved. I told you , didn't I, that his paws were swollen and that he could hardly walk? I'm very choice of my pussycat and should hate to lose him.
We are having fairly decent June weather just now. Wish it were warm enough to go swimming. It must be lovely to be situated as you are so you can go in anytime.
I'll send those silk rags, Grandma just as soon as I get back. I want to get those that Mrs. Johnson promised me. Hope your rheumatism has permanently disappeared. Have begun to read the Sea Wolf, Mummie have you read it? What do you think of it?

Muskegon, Mich.
June 9, 1915.
Dearest Mummie,
I will have time for only a postal card before the postman arrives. About the rug, I think green and brown predominate but almost any colour will harmonise with it. The walls are papered in a. brownish tone so the portieres can be almost any combination and will work well. Expect to be home Saturday. Nellie's foot well enough for her to get around now, but can't wear a shoe.  Am getting quite lonesome for my hub and he is for me. Address me at G. E. next time. Before your letters were forwarded to me. Love to G'ma.

Glen Ellyn, Ill.
July 13, 1915
Precious Mum
Am writing from Margaret's house. Could not find any of the weed you mention in our garden and have just located a sprig over here. I feel that the enclosed is the kind you want and will gather and dry some today if the town contains any. The sun is hot today so it ought to dry readily.

As the family finances are quite low, the money was very welcome. Papa gave me $20.00 to buy presents with. Got Marvin a new suit, new mittens for both children, some socks for Max and for Papa, and 2 yds. of satin to make a new underskirt for the dress mother sent me, as all the bug-stains had gone through in-to holes. Starved Rock unclear Latalle, Ill. Wednesday noon Dearest Mother: our car is parked a few feet from the river and we are waiting for it to stop raining so we can make the climb up to the park. Have you ever been here? I knew you were down in this vicinity, when you were doing organizing but can't remember whether you had been to this particular place. We had a very lovely drive down. Left early this morning before 7 o'clock and got here in about 4 hours. The distance as recorded on our speedometer is 77 miles. The scenery is beautiful all the way and the roads concrete most of the way. We came by way of Plainfield, Joliet, Morris, Marseilles and Ottowa. Saw a few cool mines lots of wheat fields with the wheat all stacked and lovely glimpses of the Fox river. Ivan Chaplin is with us. We expect to return today about 4 o'clock. Would like to stay all night but don't feel as though we could afford it. Max has his vacation this week. The birthday slip and Teddy arrived a day or two ahead of time and are very
